I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  build  on  the  findings, 
recommendations, and lessons from the TA for Strengthening Developing Member Countries’ 
Capacity in Elderly Care of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), approved in May 2016 and 
expected to be completed in May 2020, which aims to develop the capacity of developing member 
countries (DMCs) to adapt to aging populations and develop long-term care (LTC) systems and 
services.1 The country diagnostic studies conducted under the previous TA in six countries—
Indonesia, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tonga, and Viet Nam—revealed large deficits in LTC 
services, especially those providing affordable and quality care.2 Developing community-based 
services has emerged as a priority in each country. The TA will (i) continue to build the knowledge 
base on LTC for older persons; (ii) develop innovative and sustainable community-based LTC 
service models that can operate in low-income settings, deliver quality and affordable services, 
are sustainable, and have potential for replication; and (iii) strengthen knowledge sharing and 
networking on LTC in the region.3 The TA seeks to create new partnerships for service delivery 
and to address the multiple care needs of older persons in Indonesia, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, and 
Viet Nam.4 
 
2.  The TA is included in the management-approved 2019 results-based work plan of the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department.5 It is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2030, particularly operational priority 1’s agenda of addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities among the region’s most vulnerable populations.6 The proposed community-based 
care models will help develop TA and lending portfolios on adapting to aging.7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Asia and Pacific region is at the forefront of a profound demographic transition, largely 
because of increased longevity and decreased fertility rates. It is currently home to over half of 
the global population over age 60 years, and this number is expected to rise to nearly two-thirds, 
or close to 1.3 billion, by 2050. The transition is happening at an unprecedented pace, when 
traditional family support systems are weakening because of factors such as migration and

systems development in six countries (Indonesia, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tonga, and Viet Nam); capacity

2  ADB. 2018. Country Diagnostic Study (Indonesia, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tonga, Viet Nam). Manila. 
3  LTC refers to the activities undertaken by others to ensure that people, who are at risk of or experience significant 
declines in capacity, maintain a level of functional ability consistent with their basic rights, fundamental freedoms, 
and human dignity. LTC can be provided in a range of settings, including people’s homes (home care), in the 
community such as in day care centers and community centers (community care), and in residential settings such 
as nursing homes, or care homes. LTC is delivered by a range of people, including family members, health and care 
workers, and social workers; and by a range of public, private, and voluntary organizations. LTC systems are systems 
to ensure integrated LTC is appropriate, affordable, and accessible. 
4  No-objection letters will be secured before activities are implemented in these countries. 
5  The TA was initially planned as a supplementary to ADB’s TA for Strengthening Developing Members’ Capacity in 
Elderly Care, but was converted into a new TA per Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction advice in July 2019. 
6  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific.

7  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 11 November 2019.

2 
expanding  female  labor  market  participation. 8  Concurrently,  longevity  and  the  rise  in 
noncommunicable diseases are leading to increases in multi-morbidities and syndromes such as 
dementia, resulting in complex care cases requiring skilled care, in which there is very little 
capacity. To date, the majority of care provision is supplied informally by family members, who 
rarely receive any support or training. As population demographics change, there is a need to 
develop systems and services to help alleviate the widening gap between demand and supply 
and provide quality services. 
 
4.  LTC can be provided in the home, in the community, or in residential setting, by public, 
nonprofit, or private sector providers. In the capacity-building and planning process under TA 
9111,  DMCs  emphasized  that  the  design  of  LTC  systems  and  services  should  apply 
internationally recognized concepts such as (i) healthy aging, or the process of developing and 
maintaining functional ability that enables well-being in older age; (ii) aging in place, which 
emphasizes individuals aging as close to their homes and communities as possible regardless of 
age, income, or ability; and (iii) older person-centered and integrated care, which focuses on 
ensuring health and social services work with individuals and their families to coordinate the 
appropriate range of services. 
 
5.  Existing LTC is very limited in types of services, providers, and geographic and beneficiary 
coverage: services are commonly limited to high-income groups, social welfare services for the 
poorest older persons without family support, and schemes providing care through volunteers. 
The country diagnostic studies under TA 9111 found that a major challenge across all countries 
is to shift from developing policy to implementing sustainable services on the ground that are 
affordable  and  address  the  particular  contexts  and  strengths  in  each  country.  Developing 
community-based LTC service models in the four selected countries will (i) help expand access 
to the older population, and particularly the poor and vulnerable; (ii) create a clear evidence base 
for good practice; and (iii) provide an enabling environment for scaling up in the main area of 
service delivery that each country is prioritizing. 
 
6.  A key barrier to developing LTC systems is lack of financing. Investment to overcome the 
large-scale deficit in services will require decisions on (i) public investment from local and national 
governments, (ii) appropriate balance between personal and public cost-sharing for LTC, and (iii) 
mobilizing financial resources from different sources. LTC is often categorized as an unaffordable 
cost, while the absence of LTC services risks the inappropriate and avoidable overuse of acute 
health care services. Developing low-cost and effective models that can be scaled up and building 
a solid evidence base on the impact of investments are important steps to develop LTC systems 
in the region. 
 
7.  ADB has a growing portfolio in LTC and is engaging with DMCs to help them adapt to 
population aging and changing social structures. This TA is a timely response to build on policy 
development in DMCs, translate policy into implementation, share knowledge, and build up the 
evidence base. ADB can help DMCs invest in policies and programs that enable the population 
to age healthily through developing social protection policies, providing LTC services and systems, 
adapting health systems, providing training and education for the health and care workforce, 
promoting lifelong learning and skill adaption, and investing in inclusive environments, including 
infrastructure,  housing,  and  transport.  Such  investments  will  enable  older  persons  to  fully 
 
8  Gender is an important dimension in LTC. Family carers and employed carers are predominantly women. Women 
generally enter their own old age with fewer assets and lower levels of social security. Women tend to live longer 
and  with  longer  periods  of  ill  health,  which  means  they  require  more  care  themselves.  These  cumulative 
disadvantages over the life course increase their vulnerability in old age.

participate in society, including in the labor market, and reduce risks for themselves and their 
families. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: remaining poverty and inequalities for the 
region’s most vulnerable population, including older persons, addressed.9 The TA will have the 
following outcome: capacity of DMCs to develop and scale up community-based care systems 
and services for older persons improved. 10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Knowledge base on long-term care improved. This output will include 
analysis and small-scale surveys on LTC systems and services in each country. It will include 
targeted assessments and research addressing topics defined by DMC needs and prioritized in 
collaboration with ADB regional departments and other partners on the ground, such as access 
to assistive technology, financing schemes for LTC, investments in age-friendly structure, and 
social protection for carers, including family members and domestic workers. This output will help 
identify areas that will effectively address Strategy 2030’s goal of developing an inclusive and 
resilient region with a focus on the older population, including on LTC issues and options in 
support of country partnership strategies and country operations business plans.11 The TA can 
make resources available for new or ongoing small-scale activities in DMCs that provide on-the-
ground support for LTC activities or pipeline development. 
 
10.  Output 2: Capacity building program and community-based care models developed. 
For this output, the TA will design and develop innovative, affordable, and sustainable community-
based LTC service models in rural and urban areas that respond to the demand and care needs 
of older persons and build on the contexts and strengths of existing social and health care services 
in the selected countries (Indonesia, Mongolia, Sri Lanka, and Viet Nam). Based on the findings 
of the completed country diagnostic studies, and following further consultations with the national 
ministries,  local  governments,  nongovernment  organization  service  providers,  and  other 
stakeholders, four priorities were identified: (i) developing integrated health and social care 
services; (ii) creating care management systems to facilitate integration; (iii) promoting healthy 
and active aging; and (iv) enhancing human resource development of both formal and informal 
carers. ADB and DMC counterparts will agree on and implement a capacity building framework 
covering, for example, case management, human resources, and financing. 
 
11.  In Indonesia, model development will take place in three districts in Yogyakarta and will 
feature  (i)  community-based  services  that  integrate  health  and  social  care  needs  through 
collaboration between government-run community health clinics (puskesmas) and new and 
existing community organizations and that will include new services such as dementia care; (ii) 
developing care management systems and capacity; and (iii) capacity building, including training 
for family members, volunteers, care givers, and health workers. In Mongolia, the community-
based care model design will focus on (i) case management and (ii) development of three active 
aging centers (at Ulaanbaatar, aimag or provincial level, and soum or district level). Sri Lanka’s

proposed community-based care model will focus on (i) developing an age-friendly primary health 
care service model, (ii) integrating social care services such as day care through co-location and 
collaboration  with  community  service  organizations,  and  (iii)  developing  case  management 
capacity. The project in Viet Nam will focus on (i) establishing an active aging center through 
public–private partnership, and (ii) strengthening the capacity of its existing community-based 
intergenerational clubs to partner with the health sector and better deliver integrated health and 
social care services. The TA will apply technology to enhance productivity, such as simple 
management information system and application-based assessment tools. 
 
12.  The community-based service models will help fill knowledge gaps locally and create 
knowledge and a clear evidence base, which will facilitate dissemination of good practices and 
scaling up within the four countries, and potentially across the region. Capacity building will focus 
on  developing training programs  and  operational  manuals  on  care management;  providing 
competency training or skills upgrading for family and other informal care givers; and developing 
guidelines and providing training for documentation, monitoring, and evaluation of integrated care 
services, including cost-benefit analysis and assessment of quality tools. Collaboration with 
centers of excellence, including in Japan, will focus on topics such as dementia and support 
capacity building activities for the community-based care models. 
 
13.  Output 3: Knowledge-sharing and networking systems strengthened. This output will 
continue to enhance the knowledge-sharing and networking system for knowledge transfer 
established under TA 9111. The TA will design and deliver a regional conference on adapting to 
aging Asia and will tap Japanese and other experts from ministries of health, labor and welfare; 
universities and research institutes; civil society organizations; and private service providers as 
resource speakers. It will disseminate the findings from the care models to support potential 
replication within and outside of the four countries, including Pacific and East Asian countries, 
through a regional conference on community-based care models. Output 3 will (i) also support 
the design and delivery of an applied learning program (study tour) in Japan for participants from 
the four countries to learn best practices in developing policies, implementing services, and 
designing community-based care; and (ii) provide operational support to regional departments in 
developing the sector and help expand business development and investments for ADB, including 
potential collaboration with Japan International Cooperation Agency. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The estimate covers eligible costs comprising (i) consultant services; (ii) direct cost of TA 
implementation, including international and local travel, monitoring and reporting, and support for 
knowledge  product  development;  (iii)  workshops,  seminars,  training  sessions,  and  country 
working group meetings; (iv) regional conferences and forums; (v) applied learning program 
exposure (study tour) in Japan for DMC participants; (vi) small item goods, such as computer 
software packages, exercise machines, and simple medical devices for the care centers; and (vii) 
surveys.

executing and implementing agency, through collaboration with the regional department country

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions and 
staff instructions.12 Overall, the TA will require (i) an estimated 157 person-months of international 
and national consulting services and (ii) inputs from resource persons with expertise related to 
public  health,  social  work,  medicine,  gerontology,  finance,  project  management  and 
implementation, communications, and knowledge management. Of the 157 person-months of 
consulting services, the SDTG as TA Supervising Unit (TASU) will engage two international 
individual consultants (13 person-months) intermittently, who will work as a team to provide 
technical advice on developing integrated community-based care models in the four TA countries. 
TASU will also engage individual national consulting services (estimated at 24 person-months) 
for  (i)  project  coordination  and  overall  implementation  of  the  TA  and  (ii)  communications, 
knowledge management, and dissemination. TASU will identify intermittent individual consultancy 
inputs of 2 person-months international and 6 person-months national, based on the requirements 
of focused studies, surveys, research, and other activities to address emerging issues during TA

implementation. The requirements for each type of expertise and the exact length of consultant 
inputs will vary according to the area and scope of the outputs.  TASU will develop more 
comprehensive terms of reference accordingly and further clarify deliverables from consultancy 
outputs.  TASU  will  consider  output-based  contracts,  lump-sum  payments,  and  framework 
contracts for individual consultants as applicable. 
 
18.  Under output 2, ADB will recruit one firm each for Indonesia and Viet Nam, with each firm 
to include a team of one project manager and one project officer who will provide national 
expertise  to  oversee  the  implementation  of  the  community-based  care  models,  including 
management and administrative, financial, and logistical support. In Mongolia and Sri Lanka, ADB 
will engage a firm for each country, or, if there is no suitable firm, ADB will select individual 
consultants. Because local experience on the ground, qualifications of experts, and proven 
effective  engagement  with  local  multistakeholders  are  crucially  important  to  implement 
community-based care models, ADB will use either (i) consultants’ qualification selection for very 
small assignments that do not exceed $200,000; or (ii) single-source selection for very small 
assignments that do not exceed $100,000, as provided for in the staff instructions for ADB-
administered consulting services. Consultants will be required to submit final reports to ADB and 
the governments. Evaluation of their performance will be based on the findings of assessments 
by ADB and the governments. 
 
19.  Social media and websites. The existing ADB Adapting to Aging website developed 
under  the  previous  TA  will  be  updated  and  maintained  for  knowledge  dissemination  and 
networking.13 After the TA closes, the website will be maintained under SDTG activities. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Developing Innovative Community-Based Long-Term Care Systems and Services, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
